International Restrictions:
*All travellers: All travellers should familiarise themselves with the entry rules for Serbia before travel.
*If you’re fully vaccinated: If you’re fully vaccinated, you can enter Serbia without needing to test or quarantine.
*Proof of vaccination status: Serbian citizens, foreign residents or foreign travellers may present proof that they have been fully vaccinated to enter Serbia.
Serbia will accept the proof of COVID-19 vaccination record and proof of COVID-19 vaccination issued in the Crown Dependencies. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
Serbia recognises vaccination records from a number of countries – for the full list, see the section ‘Entry Regime for Foreign Citizens’ on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs website.
*If you’re not fully vaccinated: If you’re not fully vaccinated, you must provide:
• proof of a negative PCR test result issued within 48 hours of arrival. Visitors travelling from the USA may also present an antigen FIA Rapid Test result. Tests cannot be taken on arrival
• certificate of COVID-19 recovery which Serbia recognises as valid. The full list of recognised certificates is available on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs website. Serbia does not currently recognise the COVID Pass to demonstrate proof of recovery.
You should arrange to take a private test. If you need further information about entry requirements, contact the local immigration authorities or the nearest Serbian Embassy or Consulate. You should also check with your airline or travel company for the latest information.
If you do not provide one of the above mentioned documents (proof of vaccination, PCR test or an EU COVID certificate with recovery test) you must spend 10 days in self-isolation at home following entry to Serbia. You must report to a healthcare centre within 24 hours of entering Serbia by registering on the e-Health portal. If you have travelled outside Serbia and are returning within 48 hours, you may present a negative PCR test result issued from Serbia, provided it was issued within 48 hours prior to re-entry into Serbia.
*If you’ve had COVID-19 in the past year: You can not use the COVID Pass to demonstrate proof of COVID-19 recovery when entering Serbia.
*Children and young people: Children aged 12 and under are exempt from COVID-19 entry requirements, provided the parent/adult accompanying has complied with them.
Children aged 12 to 17 may enter Serbia under the rules for fully vaccinated or not fully vaccinated travellers. In addition they may enter without complying with those rules but must take a PCR or antigen test within 48 hours of arrival.
*If you’re transiting through Serbia: Transiting is when you pass through one country on the way to your final destination. Foreign nationals transiting through Serbia are exempt from COVID-19 entry requirements if the transiting period is under 12 hours.
*Exemptions: Exemptions to Serbia’s COVID-19 entry requirements include:
• citizens of Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Hungary, North Macedonia and Montenegro, entering Serbia directly from those countries
• citizens or residents of Serbia when entering directly from the countries above and the Republic of Croatia
• foreign nationals transiting Serbia (up to 12 hours).
• crew of international cargo (road and river) transport (time limits apply)
• crews and cabin crews of aircraft arriving in and transiting Serbia
• children aged 12 years and under, provided the parent/adult accompanying has complied with the entry requirements.
Further details can be found on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.


Internal Restrictions:
*Public spaces and services: There are nationwide rules in place restricting movement and limiting activity. Protective face masks are mandatory in medical facilities and recommended in all public spaces indoors, and, outdoors when the area is crowded. Failure to wear a mask when required will incur a fine. Self-isolation, when required, will be enforced.
Additional rules and penalties vary in different towns and cities, and rules can change rapidly. You should follow the latest local guidance and check news outlets regularly for up to date information.
Further restrictions may be introduced, both nationwide and locally, including at short notice. Infringements of these procedures may result in fines and/or a prison sentence.
*If you test positive for coronavirus while in Serbia, you will be required to self-isolate at an address of your choosing for at least 7 days, likely a hotel or private residence, at your own cost. You may be contacted by the authorities and be hospitalised if deemed medically necessary. Minors will be subject to the same regulations as adults
